description.narrative: Mainstreaming PA management into provincial development and sector planning process

PA system and its management mainstreamed within the provincial sectoral and development planning framework at the provincial level: indicated by clear inclusion of due consideration and concrete measures for biodiversity conservation and PA development, as well as ear marked budget in the sectoral development plans at provincial levels and in the (national) 13th 5-year plan.

comment.narrative: No sectoral plans integrate PA objectives Development plans include no vision and development plan for PAs and no link is made between the PAs and development, nor no concrete measure for biodiversity conservation

At least 3 sectoral plans integrate consideration of PAs and of biodiversity conservation measures 13th Five-Year Plan recognises clear linkage between PAs and provincial development, and includes PA- and biodiversity-related targets and budgets

"1+5" model was formed that stands for Provincial 13th Five-Year Plan ("1"), Provincial Development and Reform Commission, 13th Five-Year Plan of Land Resources, 13th Five-Year Plan of Agro-husbandry Department, 13th Five-Year Plan of Water Conservancy Department,13th Five-Year Plan of Environmental Protection Department ("5"). 13th Five-Year Plans were integrated with BSAP through inter-sectoral advisory group that was facilitated by GEF project.

description.narrative: Threats to PAs from infrastructure placement (roads, dams) and other adverse forms of land use avoided, mitigated or offset, leading to more effective conservation in Qinghai's PA system covering 251,665km2.

comment.narrative: No procedure in place to deal with incompatible developments
Official standards for infrastructure development and operation within the PAs are developed and operationalised, with clear rehabilitation/offset mechanism.

'Transportation and Traffic Infra-construction Environmental Protection Regulation and Technical Guidelines' and 'Infra-construction Environmental Protection Regulation of State Grid Qinghai Company and Technical Guidelines' was reviewed and will be enacted in 2015.

description.narrative: Increasing PA management effectiveness through strengthened institutional and staff capacities
Capacity development scorecard (%) for the protected area system.

comment.narrative: PMO and Wildlife and Nature Reserve Management Bureau conducted the mid-term capacity Development Scorecard assessment. The Score is 63.6% in May 2015. To date, 17 batches of training courses with covering 11 topics were delivered to 440 trainees including 127 women(28.8%) who are from PA managers and technical staff as well as community wardens.

description.narrative:
Strategic plans prepared for PA institutions and procedures and investment, and PA staff numbers dramatically increased
- Permanent staff
- Temporary staff

comment.narrative:
No strategic plans
160

Strategic Plan developed and adopted
360
150

Permanent Staff: 231
Temporary staff(Contracted):273
According to the official document provided by Personnel Division of QFD, there is an increase of 118 staff in PA staff who are mainly forestry policemen of SNNR and QFD as well as staff of Qilian Mountain NR and an increase of 273 in contracted staff (Ecological public service positions) during the year of 2013-2014. Major reason is based on nature reserve institutional strengthening strategy plan of Province in order to enhance enforcement of PA management and forestry management. GEF promoted the process of the strengthening plan through nature reserve management plan development and offered advice on nature reserve institutional strengthening.

description.narrative: Province’s system level PA financing increased to close the existing annual financing gap of US$ 4.6 million for basic expenditure scenario (tracked with PA financial sustainability scorecard)

comment.narrative: US$ 2 million / year
US$ 6.6 million per year

US$19.3 million per year
According to financial scorecard in 2014. The total revenue of PA system was respectively US$2.83million, US$19.3 million in 2011 and in 2014. Of which, 7.21 million is field operational fee and 10.54 million is an investment for infrastructure construction. The financial data of 7 nature reserves is only available since the other nature reserves don't have discretionary authority, independent financial accounts. The reason for financial increase are investment from the central government includes infrastructure, capacity building, conservation, Research and publicity and education and other investment from external cooperative research and ecotourism.
GEF levers co-finance from the government together to made its contribution of $2.37million to PAs.

description.narrative: Ratio of total PA budget spent on field operations raised to narrow spending gap

comment.narrative:
10% of PA revenue
spent on field operations

30% of PA revenue
spent on field operations

19.2% in 2014.
According to the financial scorecards, the total revenue is US$13,054,000,of which spending on operations and infrastructures are respectively US$2,514,000 and US$10,540,000. The field operational cost of PAs accounts for 19.2% of the total expenditure in 2014. This ratio would be fluctuant in terms of the amount of infrastructure investment of PAs sponsored by the central government.

description.narrative: Reduction in illegal incident cases within the NRs eg.poaching, illegal harvesting, illegal-grazing, etc.

comment.narrative:
Currently no monitoring system in place.
Baseline for the number of illegal incidents will be estimated at onset of the project.

Functioning policing records system with links to police/ court cases and an enhanced policing mandate of NR staff.
Routine report forms designed for numerical analysis.
Incidents reduced to 50% of the baseline level.

According to the annual report of Forestry Police Bureau of QFD, illegal incidents were respectively as follow:
2011: 1942 cases in total consisted of 34 criminal cases and 1908 administrative cases.
2012: 1968 cases in total consisted of 22 criminal cases and 1946 administrative cases.
2013: 1872 cases in total consisted of 24 criminal cases and 1848 administrative cases.
2014: 1199 cases in total consisted of 56 criminal cases and 1143 administrative cases.

description.narrative: Annual income diverted to PA management from eco-compensation agreements (excluding funds arising from the Sanjiangyuan Ecological Construction Plan)

comment.narrative: US$1.0m

$1.589 million per year.
The financial resources are from the central government excluding the Sanjiangyuan Ecological Construction Plan that is eco-compensation arrangement from the central government.
According to the financial scorecard assessment, the total investment to PAs was $13 million in 2014. Among which, operational cost is $2.514 million and infrastructure investment is $10.54million which includes infrastructure, conservation, capacity building, Research and publicity and education. However, rarely in road and visitor center construction. If excluding the investment to SNNR, the investment to other PAs is about $1.589 million.

description.narrative: More representative PA system approved with most of ‘major vegetation types’ represented (5% coverage) in the NNR's

comment.narrative: 13 of 30 habitats

22 of 30 habitats
(addition of desert and Qilian montane habitats, with an overall increase of 18,000,000 ha in the provincial PA system)

Wildlife and Nature Reserve Management Bureau of Qinghai Forestry Department thought that the provincial PAs Development Plan (2011-2020) has covered with more representatives of eco-region and vegetation types, in which, some targets have been achieved. Instead, they prefer to develop Qinghai PA monitoring plan, which is consistence with State Forestry Administration's funding strategy and the strengthening of PAs management effectiveness is one of GEF project's priorities. In terms of this consideration, GEF sponsored the development of Qinghai PA monitoring plan and PMO asked a specialist to conduct a mapping analysis between vegetations and existing PAs in 2015, which indicates the representatives of vegetations and eco-regions in Qinghai and gaps of PAs coverage and also includes the recommendations to future PA system planning.

description.narrative: Awareness surveys among communities show increased positive attitude towards PA conservation

comment.narrative:
Baseline awareness TBD by Knowledge Attitudes & Practice (KAP) survey at onset of project according to Participatory Rural Assessment in Qumahe Township in 2013
- Angla Village: 76% of interviewees were concerned for wildlife, 76% of interviewees can identify at least 2 endangered species.
- Duoxiu Village: 86% of interviewees were concerned for wildlife, 80% of interviewees can identify at least 2 endangered species.
- Cuochi Village:95% of interviewees were concerned for wildlife.
Baseline + 50% positive attitude

The project conducted baseline awareness assessment(KAP) in 4 pilot villages of Qumahe Township in 2013 though it was not so comprehensive. Environmental awareness was presented very high among the 4 pilot villages as there have been community development support extended there for several years The GEF project has also made contributions to raising awareness among local communities residing within or near PA’s. According to the results of MTR questionnaire interview in Duoxiu and Cuochi Villages, awareness among target communities has been enhanced that about 95% of interviewees are satisfied with the GEF project, knowing the co-management agreement and benefiting to herders respectively.

The protection rate of natural wetlands was 45.33% in 2013, and increased to 46.06% in 2014.

description.narrative: 1.2. Ecosystem Health Index (EHI) monitoring systems for monitoring wetland health fine-tuned and in place for the entire sub-system, with a focus to reduce threats.

comment.narrative: Currently no use. The EHI has been developed during the PPG stage but will be fine-tuned based on implementation experience emerging from the provincial projects and other existing indexes (e.g., the WEEIS) (Annex 1).
Fine-tuning and wide adoption of EHI at the sub-system wetland PA level.

description.narrative: External threats to Wetland PAs reduced through mainstreaming wetland PA considerations in sector planning
2.1.a. Safeguards from sector practices for MOA, MOWR, MLWR, and MEP in place and in use.

comment.narrative: No safeguards for wetland PAs.
Safeguards in the form of standards and procedures in place for each sector, and used centrally by SFA to avoid threats from external sectors.

description.narrative: 2.2. Increased national financing for wetland PA management (funds and number of mechanisms) as recorded in the financial sustainability scorecard

comment.narrative: Baseline amount is the national budget allocation of US$87.95 Million per year for operation (US$ 35,170,000) and infrastructure (US$ 52,780,000). Financing mechanisms are mainly budget allocations. There is an eco-compensation program, however the funding provincial governments receive is not linked to PA management.

Budget allocations for PA management operation increased by 50% over the baseline from national level sources (any sources, to be developed during implementation); and new sustainable financing mechanisms for PAs established and operational including earmarking of eco-compensation program funding for wetland PA management.

The project helps SFA in allocation of funding for wetland programme nationally. The national budget allocation rises fast and now at US$300 Million in 2014 (263.01million for operations; 36.99 million for infrastructure covering. 63 projects with about 500,000 hectares wetlands added as beneficiary. The policy of central government subsidies to wetlands have been implemented very well in 2014, the central government allocated special funds to start pilot programme of farmland to wetlands, pilot programme of wetland ecological compensation , pilot wetland conservation incentives, and the continued implementation of wetland conservation and restoration programmes, 268 projects were arranged, the total amount subsidies of 2014 was about USD263.01million, , increased 1.2 and 5.4 times respectively than 2013. The specified funding allocation of 2014 is as following: USD82.84 million for wetlands conservation and restoration; USD24.67 million for pilot programme of returning farmland to wetlands; USD 105.2million for wetland ecological compensation programme; about USD49.31 million for pilot wetland conservation incentives.
These figure already exceed targets for funding set forth in PD.

description.narrative: Increased knowledge management, lessons sharing, and awareness for wetland PAs.
3.1. Improved data sharing platform regularly updated, as indicated by use levels of data providers and data users including their usefulness.

comment.narrative: No use. Currently, the SFA lacks a comprehensive system to manage wetland data at the sub-system level.

Data sharing platform in use in the form of a virtual database, containing basic wetland PA data from all the PA agencies providing necessary information for wetland PA managers for their management decision making

Data base development has been designed as a very important part under outcome 3, during the period of project implementation, OWCM/SFA has taken the lead and organized a group of experts to establish the virtual database by Chinese partner supporting funding based on the demands and needs of wetland development in China. And the project funds planned for this purpose has been decided to shift for other policies research through the discussion with OWCM/SFA and UNDP China.

description.narrative: 3.2. Public and government have better understanding and better access to information about wetland issues, indicated by results of the KAP surveys (Annex 4)

comment.narrative: KAP survey has been commissioned through the PPG and a baseline has been measured for the national level project in Beijing and for some of the provincial projects. The baseline is a score of 111.5 of 216 in Beijing (52%).
30% improvement in KAP survey results (i.e., a score of 173 or 82%).
indicator scores remain unchanged as the baseline, i.e. 111.5 of 216 in Beijing (52%), and will be updated by the MTR.

description.narrative: 3.3. Magnitude and coverage of lessons disseminated.

comment.narrative: No program level system to track or disseminate lessons.

Programmatic monitoring system in place as per the Program Framework and program level reporting is in place. Lessons documented and shared widely. Wetland PA Program Steering and Coordination Forum established

PSC meeting (2015) has been conducted successfully on Apr.22-23,2015 in Honghu county, Heibei Province;
Project website( www.gefwetland.com) has been established and operated, information, experiences and lessons sharing are more widely and efficient; Wechat group has been established and use for daily communication among all projects stakeholders

description.narrative: Environment - policy, planning and administration

To strengthen the management effectiveness of the wetland protected area system in Hainan in response to existing and emerging threats to the globally significant biodiversity and essential ecosystem services

The area of ecosystems covered by Hainan’s terrestrial PA system increases by at least 40,000 ha with improved coverage of under-represented types by 2018 in line with the draft PA System Master Plan, project strategy and action plan for the wetland PA subsystem and climate change resilience strategy.

In 2013, Hainan Forestry Department promoted the establishment of 1 national forest park and approved the establishment of 12 provincial forest parks. The coverage of Hainan terrestrial PAs has been increased by 29,516 ha.
From 2014 till now, 2 new provincial nature reserves are in the process of applying for approval, which are E'xianling NR (forest ecosystem) with an area of 4,490ha and Yanding NR (mangrove ecosystem) with an area of 160ha. A privately-owned wetland park, Baolinggang WP with an area of about 100ha, is now under design and planned to start construction by end of 2015. The wetland park is owned by a renowned real estate company, Luneng Group, and they are keen to follow the ecological concept in the wetland park construction with the support of the project. A memorandum of understanding is drafted by the Project to include the wetland park as one demonstration site of Hainan GEF project. However, the area of vegetation type is not yet updated, because the Hainan PA Master Plan is not yet approved and this category was not applied during the 2nd National Wetland Inventory Assessment. This issue will be put forward during the next PSC meeting by end of 2015.

To better improve the capacity of PA management, a professional competency standard for Hainan NRs' staff was drafted with reference to the "Competence Standards for Protected Area Jobs in South East Asia" developed by ASEAN Regional Center for Biodiversity Conservation(ARCBC), and on the basis of field assessment in 17 representative NRs, which are under respective supervision by Hainan Forestry Department, Hainan Land, Environment and Resources Department and Hainan Marine and Fisheries Department. The draft has been revised according to the advice of a panel of experts, officials and NR representatives, and will be finalized by Aug. 2015. Furthermore, a training needs’ assessment was conducted in Oct. 2014 among all project related PAs, topics for future training were identified for PAs' staff at different level. By end of 2015, the METT evaluation will be conducted during the MTR.

In Sep. 2014, the revised "Hainan Provincial Regulation of Nature Reserve Management" was adopted by the Hainan Provincial People's Congress. According to the new regulation, the cost for provincial NR shall be included into the provincial budget plan, which can help to reduce the financing gap. By end of 2015, the financial sustainability evaluation will be conducted during the MTR.

description.narrative: Improved protection and management of Hainan’s ecosystems through expansion, consolidation and sustainable financing of the provincial PA system
Financing Plan for the expanded PA system under Hainan Master Plan for the PA System including strategy and action plan for the wetland PA subsystem

Financing Plan approved for the expanded PA system under Hainan Master Plan for the PA System including strategy and action plan for the wetland PA subsystem

The Master Plan for Hainan Nature Reserves Development is still under elaboration, which is led by the Hainan Environment Protection Department (formerly the Hainan Land Environment and Resources Department). Besides, based on the result of 2nd national wetland inventory, the master plan for Hainan wetland conservation is now under elaboration. The financial plan for the wetland PA sub-system will be developed afterwards.

US$ 8.06 million / year

US$19.92 million per year

According to the statistic from the HFD, in 2014 the yearly overall financing for PA system is US$12.478 million from both national and provincial government. 4 project sites received in total about US$ 2.97million (CNY18.4 million) from the provincial government for wetland restoration by the end of 2014. The fund is mainly used in mangrove afforestation, converting ponds back to mangroves and infrastructure construction, such as boundary markers, watch towers, bird watching hides, entrance gates etc.

To enhance the capacity in mangrove wetland restoration and management, the project organized 4 trainings for officials from local bureaus of forestry, land environment & resources, marine and fisheries, finance and tourism. Among the total participants of 141, 60 are government officials including 12 female. The capacity assessment will be carried out again during the MTR.

description.narrative: Strengthened protection, participatory management and restoration of mangrove forests through the development of a Mangrove PA Network (MPAN)

Operational MPAN is evident through:
i) Official recognition of Mangrove PA Network in Hainan PA system plans.
ii) Network coordination centre and training base established at Dongzhaigang NNR
iii) All MPAN sites upload and update required site information to MPAN database according to agreed protocols

comment.narrative: Mangrove PAs are not networked, lack of common management methods and standards, limited information exchange

Operational MPAN evident through:
i) Official recognition of Mangrove PA Network in Hainan PA system plans.
ii) Network coordination centre and training base established at Dongzhaigang NNR
iii) All MPAN sites upload and update required site information to MPAN database according to agreed protocols

In Dec. 26, 2014, the establishment meeting of the MWPAN was held in Haikou. Directors from 10 project sites and the deputy director from Hainan Wild Animal and Plant Conservation Bureau, which is responsible for Hainan PAs management, attended the meeting. The Declaration of the Network was discussed, approved and signed by all member PAs on the meeting. The declaration states that the Network will organize at least one meeting per year, and a theme will be selected during the meeting, which is to be the key focus for all member PAs for the year. The theme for 2015 is biodiversity monitoring. A timetable for monthly monitoring was agreed upon by all members.
Necessary equipment including meeting room audio/visual equipment, professional cameras for bird photography and computers etc. were procured for the establishment of a training center in Dongzhaigang in the second half of 2014. After that, a training event was organized in Dongzhaigang on species identification and monitoring in Nov. 2014.

After a training in March 2014, the survey was carried out in all project sites in April with the support of Dr. MacKinnon. In June, the EHI report and the baseline score was finalized and distributed to all sites. In addition, based on the survey, a monitoring protocol for each site was also developed by the specialist.

description.narrative: Increased protection status of selected wetland related reserves, taking full account of access and benefit sharing rights of indigenous / minority ethnic group stakeholders. **Yinggeling is a forested catchment area for Haikou area

comment.narrative:
During the inception workshop, the baseline and target of this indicator was discussed and proposed to be changed. The proposed change were as below:
1) change the listed Haiwei WP(not yet a Provincial WP) to Dongfang PNR, and its baseline level is PNR and the target is NNR.
2) change the target for Fanjia PNR to the demonstration PNR of wetland type.
3) change the target for Sanya CNR to demonstration CNR.
For the baseline, the Haiwei Wetland Park is not yet a provincial park. During the inception workshop, this problem was discussed and proposed to change to Dongfang PNR, of which the baseline level is PNR and the target is NNR. However, the approval procedure of this revision is not completed. So this issue will be re-discussed and confirmed during the next PSC meeting by end of 2015 before asking for approval by UNDP regional office .
Through about a year of preparation, application and assessment, by end of Dec. 2014, the state council announced that the Yinggeling NR was upgraded to national level Nature Reserve.
The project is now looking into the possibility to support the Dongfang PNR to get international designation, which is to be listed as an international site under the East Asian Australasian Flyway Programme, as the first step to apply for NNR.

description.narrative: Increase in the number of wintering Black-faced Spoonbills Platalea minor in Hainan

comment.narrative: Wintering population of 76 BF Spoonbills
Wintering population of 100 BF Spoonbills with a stable or increasing trend

According to the result of the International Black-faced Spoonbill Census in every January, the number in Hainan slightly increased from 44 in 2012 to 56 in 2015.
In Aug. 2014, the local government planted about 57.3ha of mangrove seedling on the mudflat and beach inside the NR for the purpose of restoring mangrove forest and attracting more BF spoonbill. However, according to bird specialists, the planting efforts may have a negative impact. So based on the specialists' advice and previous studies on BF spoonbill, the project wrote an advice letter to the local government. In addition, during CTA's visits to Dongfang, this issue was openly discussed among the government officials. Now the government was highly aware of the problem and willing to take measures to make change.

description.narrative: Viable alternative options are demonstrated for target communities impacting mangrove resources at Dongzhaigang and Qinglangang that result in more sustainable resource use and include the equitable representation and involvement of women.

comment.narrative: No assistance available from PA system to help local communities with economic opportunities
New co-management structures are established that support and strengthen alternative livelihood options for target communities, including equitable representation and involvement of women.

The project made efforts to explore feasible alternative livelihood for local residents around NRs, such as bee-raising, crab-raising etc. In Dongzhaigang, 4 households were selected and trained to demonstrate bee-raising.

description.narrative: Increased area of mangrove cover within and adjacent to project demonstration reserves through replanting activities in unproductive aquaculture ponds and other suitable areas

comment.narrative:
See table inset below for baseline area of mangrove cover and area of existing replanting efforts at selected sites
Site Mangrove Area Existing Replanted Area

<!--10-->
Dongfang PNR 50 ha Sanya CNR 50 ha Total 1000+ ha

During the inception workshop, the target of 1,000 ha for mangrove replanting was perceived to be unrealistic, because the available land in NRs are very limited. So it was proposed to change the wording of "mangrove replanting" into "mangrove wetland restoration". However, the approval procedure of this revision is not completed. So this issue will be re-discussed and confirmed during the next PSC meeting by end of 2015 before asking for approval by UNDP regional office .
Moreover, during the project implementation, it was found that the government stressed too much on mangrove replanting instead of restoring the ecosystem service functions of mangrove wetland. Even worse, fast-growing exotic mangrove species were commonly used in the replanting. To resolve the problem, in March, 2014 the project organized a mangrove restoration expert discussion workshop at the provincial level and in May and June, 4 trainings were conducted for officials from different government apartments in Sanya, Danzhou, Dongfang and Wenchang.
So far, the replanting area for selected sites are:
Dongzhaigang NNR 133.3ha (finished)
Qinglanggang PNR 53.3ha (ongoing)
Xinying NWP 8 ha (ongoing)
Dongfang PNR 57.3ha (finished)
Sanya CNR 36.7ha (ongoing)
Total 288.6ha

description.narrative: Improved integration of wetland conservation into development and sectoral planning and practices through a strengthened PA System Management Framework including economic valuation of ecosystem services
Sector specific standards for tourism and coastal fisheries are consistent with international standards for responsible ecotourism and fishery practices

comment.narrative: Existing plans and practices for key sectors including tourism and fishery development do not adequately address key issues for wetland PAs

Approval and demonstrated voluntary uptake of sector specific standards for tourism by 20 companies (based on ecotourism category of the ASEAN Tourism Standards) and coastal fisheries by 2 villages (based on the FAO Code of Conduct for Responsible Fisheries and related guidelines)

The project had contacted Haikou Tourism Development Committee to get the draft Regulation on the Management of Mangrove and Rural Tourism Zone. Further study is to be made to look into the existing regulations and plans.

description.narrative: Key development and sectoral plans such as the 13th 5-year plan and subsidiary plans for key sectors include explicit reference to conservation of the Mangrove PA Network

comment.narrative: 12th 5-year plan and subsidiary plans for tourism, fisheries, water resources and other key sectors do not adequately address wetland conservation

13th 5-year plan and subsidiary plans for tourism (including the Hainan International Tourism Island Master Plan), fisheries, water resources and other key sectors include explicit reference to conservation of the Mangrove PA Network

To promote wetland mainstreaming, the project encouraged and invited relevant government officials to visit project sites and participate in project activities. Moreover, cross-sectoral meetings with relevant local government agencies including environment, water resources, tourism, marine and fishery, forestry were organized in Wenchang, Dongfang and Sanya during the CTA visit in Hainan. Such meetings are proved to be effective and influential as the government official can i) learn about the project ii) have some technical capacity building part to it iii) also facilitate sharing and learning amongst each other.

description.narrative: Establishment of a suitable cross-sectoral body at provincial level to facilitate mainstreaming of wetland conservation into sectoral policies, plans and practices

comment.narrative: Coordination between wetland PA subsystem management and development planning and sectoral planning occurs but is largely responsive and ad hoc

A permanent cross-sectoral body is established at provincial level, formally recognized by all sectors and proactively promoting and facilitating strategic inter-sectoral coordination on wetland conservation

To promote cross sectoral cooperation and the wetland mainstreaming, the project has encouraged and invited relevant government officials to visit project sites and participate in project activities. Moreover, cross-sectoral meetings and training workshops with relevant local government agencies including environment, water resources, tourism, marine and fishery, forestry were organized in Wenchang, Dongfang, Danzhou, Sanya. Such meetings are proved to be effective and influential as the government official can i) learn about the project ii) have some technical capacity building part to it iii) also facilitate sharing and mutual learning.
To establish a specialized cross-sectoral body on wetland conservation is perceived to be of little chance, because there are already many such bodies on different issues, which are mainly related to a specific national project of significance. So that, during the 2nd PSC meeting, it was approved that the cross-sectoral body will be built on the current PSC by trying to include more government departments.

description.narrative: Awareness of the value of Hainan’s mangrove ecosystem services is increased across a cross-section of provincial audiences (the end-of-project assessment will include gender disaggregated data)

comment.narrative:

For major activities of the project, such as the Bird Festival in Dongzhaigang and the MWPAN establishment meeting, media were invited to report. Moreover, with efforts of the communication specialist, reports about birds, wetland resources, mangroves can frequently be seen in the newspaper. In addition, news about project activities was also released on the UNDP China official website.
Several publications were developed, including 2 leaflets of project introduction and common birds in Dongzhaigang, and two handbooks of "Mangrove Plants in Hainan" and "Birds in Dongzhaigang".
In the beginning of 2015, two major awareness-raising events were co-hosted by the project with Hainan Forestry Department, which is the celebration of World Wetland Day in Feburary and the Bird-Loving Week and the World Wildlife Day in March. According to official statistics, in total 2.5 thousand visitors attended the two events, which mostly were urban residents, students from primary and middle school, government officials, NGOs etc.

description.narrative: Improved data sharing platform for Hainan’s wetland PAs is established, regularly updated and in frequent use by a range of data providers and target audiences

comment.narrative: Data on Hainan’s wetland PAs are dispersed, largely unavailable online, and not regularly updated
A centralized database on Hainan’s wetland PAs is accessible to online users, updated on a monthly basis and registers at least 100 hits per month

To develop an on-line database platform, the Project contracted the Network Research & Development Dept. (NRDD) of Research Institute of Forest Resource Information Techniques under Chinese Academy of Forestry. After several rounds of discussion together with the NR management and NRDD, the content of the database was formulated and the first draft of the database platform is foreseen in Sept. 2015.

description.narrative: Improved capacity scorecard (SC) scores of Forestry Department for participatory approaches in PA planning and management (Q8 in SC), PA staff competencies (Q9 & 16-19 in SC), and public awareness and support (Q21 in SC)

comment.narrative:

Average score for Q8,9, 16-19 and 21 is 2.4 at minimum, through inter alia the following improvements:
Majority of PAs in AMWL with updated and participatorially prepared management plans, including co-management components
More systematic staff training program designed and initiated
Accessible data and information sharing platform developed under supervision of XFD in support of PA management operationalised
Data sharing platform includes ‘freeform’ categories for observations or information (incl. complaints) submitted anonymously or by the public
This work expected to be done in 2016.

description.narrative: Existence of operational safeguard measures to protect wetland habitat and biodiversity from infrastructure placement and mining

comment.narrative:
EIA procedures are not adequately followed leading to undesirable impacts from infrastructure construction and mining.
No legal obligation for post-mining rehabilitation.
No system for reporting malfeasance, or through which to submit formal concerns or complaints or to make suggestions

EIA law is strictly enforced for construction and mining projects affecting wetland PAs, with full participation of the wetland and PA management authorities.
Clear standards are officially set up and enforced with minimum requirements for post-extraction site restoration of mining sites.
Hotline contact number operationalized – also see the information platform above – with referral system (i.e., to other sectors) in place

EIA laws enforced for construction and mining projects affecting wetland PAs, ecosystem experts have chances to participate and provide suggestions on relevant sectors project which influence wetland habitat and biodiversity.

No mining occurs inside PAs in AMWL region
The human activities in NR of Altay region has been control effectively, no outside people in NR except the herders and management staffs. No new mining contract signed.

description.narrative: Viable alternative options are developed for herding communities, that offset economic dependency on grazing inside PAs

comment.narrative: No assistance available from PA system to help local communities with economic opportunities
New co-management structures are in place, which support and strengthen alternative livelihood options for Kazakh herders (and other forms of collaboration)

Trying on developing of alternative plan for herding communities. Supported tourism cooperative of Sandaohaizi increase income through eco-tourism. Organized 4 phase handicrafts training in Chagan township, which helped herders increase income.

comment.narrative: No conservation action plan for Chinese beaver No relationship between two adjacent NRs in Altai Mtns

Established cooperation relationship with Tavan Bogd NP of Mongolia, had communications and visits for two times and Memorandum of Cooperation was signed.

description.narrative: Operational budgets for PAs in AMWL increase

description.narrative: The adoption and development of a ‘community co-management’ approach to conservation in Liangheyuan Nature Reserve demonstrates improved management effectiveness for a wetland PA in the Altai Mountains and Wetland Landscape
Reduction in biodiversity pressure from overgrazing

comment.narrative:
7,000 herding families graze livestock in the NR in summer, incl. 170 families (approx. 40,000 stock) in ecologically sensitive Sandaohaizi wetland
Management zones in Liangheyuan NR not rationalized

Livestock numbers reduced by 20% in Sandaohaizi wetland, with economic burden to local people offset with alternative (complementary) livelihoods
Zoning of Liangheyuan NR re-assessed and modified based on EHI surveys with illegal mining banned in core/buffer zones and grazing banned in core zones

Some of the herder families from Sandaohaizi are trying to change from herding to business, livestock numbers reduced a little, no statistic data yet. The core zone of Liangheyuan NR is under strict management ,no human activities. In addition of local herders, the activities in buffer zone is reducing.

description.narrative: Enhanced socio-economic options to compensate for lost opportunities improving local economic situation

comment.narrative:
Community ecotourism not present in project area (Liangheyuan NR)
Avg. household income is 1,980 CNY/year in Sandaohaizi community

At least 3 community tourism ventures established, bringing benefit to at least 30 families serving as a model for up-scaling
Average household income for park residents increased by at least 20%, as a result of new livelihood opportunities

Supported tourism cooperative which established by 10 herder families of Sandaohaizi, increased income through eco-tourism. Also organized training courses of handicrafts and cooking in Sandaohaizi area, trying to enhance socio-economic options.

description.narrative: Reduction in biodiversity pressure from mining

comment.narrative: 6,800 ha of PA land in NR is still threatened by mining activities
Illegal gold mining activities stopped in NR, and restoration of 800 ha of land previously degraded by mining
Totally stopped the illegal mining activities in Liangheyuan NR. And covered 300 ha of previous degraded land, planted blackcurrant in some part of the restoration area.

Through visit the local families and monitoring known the population of threatened species are increasing, can notice ibex, red deer regularly; and spotted the brown bear, wolve and sable by infrared camera.

description.narrative: Status of selected indicator species that are rare and threatened (including inter alia: Lynx lynx, Ursus arctos arctos, Alces alces, Lepus timidus, Tetrao parvirostris, Bonasia bonasia, Grus vipio, Grus leucogeranus, Aix galericulata, Brachymystax lenok, Astragalus mongholicus, Chosenia arbutifolia)

comment.narrative: Baseline survey of selected indicator species in Year 1 (see methodological plan in Table 9)
Key wildlife populations maintained or increasing;

Indicator species listed are mostly very rare and not easy to quantify. Recent surveys and photos confirm they are all still present.
Model sites Duobukuer and Genhe have established qualitative diversity baseline of fish, birds, mammals, herps and wetland plants. EHI scores of those sites show stable or increasesin selected indicators since baseline surveys of 2013.
5 additional sites have all now identified their own indicator species and established new baselines. Deployment of automatic cameras will help add quantifiable basis for assessing indicator changes in future.
Lynx lynx - Very rare but occasionally seen Ursus arctos - Rare and absent from most areas Alces alces – widespread, scarce but stable
Lepus timidus – widespread, commonly seen Tetrao parvirostris - rare but still present Bonasia bonasia – Common and often seen Grus vipio, Grus leucogeranus – seasonal visitors
Aix galericulatus – common and breeding well Brachymystax lenox – getting rare but still present
Astragalus mongholicus – plant stable
Chosenia arbutifolia- populations stable, habitat OK.

description.narrative: Number of new jobs created for local people from sustainable use of the PAs

comment.narrative: 900 (HJ 600, IM 300) of which 115 women and indigenous people
125 new jobs were created, including 70 in HJ (additional 100 are expected in the near future) and 55(35 men, 20 women) in IM.-to be done by PMUs.

description.narrative: Development planning frameworks for the Daxing’anling Landscape provide the enabling environment for expanding the forest and wetland PA network and mainstreaming biodiversity as an asset for sustainable development
Biodiversity conservation strengthened through monetary and non-monetary valuation of ecosystem services

comment.narrative: No comprehensive (evidence-based) valuation of the ecosystem services exists
Investment in biodiversity, PAs and a regional green development strategy is being supported through widely communicated assessment of the value of the Daxing’anling’s ecosystem services

The valuation is on-going through a subcontract entitled “Valuation of Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services of The Daxing’anling Landscape”, to provide a basis on PAs’ and a regional green development strategy in the region.

description.narrative: Threats reduced by mainstreaming biodiversity conservation and the PA system within the sectoral and development planning frameworks, indicated by effective intersectoral coordination and plans incorporating biodiversity conservation measures

comment.narrative: No inter-sectoral coordination mechanism for biodiversity conservation and PAs exist at Landscape level Sectoral plans do not include adequate measures for biodiversity conservation 12th 5 year plan includes chapter for biodiversity conservation but needs mainstreaming throughout

Inter-sectoral Group(s) for coordinating biodiversity conservation functioning and steering the process at landscape level
At least 2 sectoral plans (among forestry, tourism, agriculture, water, mining) integrate biodiversity conservation measures, including clear safeguard measures in sector practices
13th 5 year-Plan recognises clear linkage between biodiversity and PAs and sectoral development, and includes PA and biodiversity-related targets

The Project Coordination Groups (PCG) of Heilongjiang and Inner Mongolia FMAs established, comprising focal points from relevant sectors/divisions (including conservation, science, water, environment, silviculture, tourism, planning, industry, agriculture, livestock and fishery, finance, communications as well as the demonstration site FMB and representatives of local communities); the first meeting held, respectively, to advise the project and promote mainstreaming of biodiversity and protected areas into key development plans. Plans incorporating biodiversity conservation measures formulated or drafted within the reporting period include 1) HJ: (1) "Ecological Conservation and Improvement Plan of Heilongjiang Province" (2014-2020) promulgated by the Forestry Department of Heilongjiang provincial government, "Plan of Building Daxing’anling Eco Civilization (Years 2013-2020) ", "Plan of Building Eco Civilization (2013- 2020) in Daxing'anling" and " Daxing'anling Low-Emission Development Plan" by the Administrative Office of Development and Reform Commission of Heilongjiang, "13th‘5-year Plan’ of the Forest Group Company ", "Plan of Building Eco- Civilization Demonstration Areas in Daxing’anling (Years 2014 - 2018)", " Programme of Building Forest Ecological Conservation and Building National Demonstration PAs in Daxing’anling, Heilongjiang" by the Forestry Group Company, "Implementation Plan of Daxing’anling Ecological Conservation and Improvement" by the Provincial Administrative Office. Moreover, Nanwenhe NNR and other 7 NNRs have been listed in "Heilongjiang Provincial Wetland Eco-tourism Plan" by Provincial Tourism Bureau; 2) in IM, provisions of “Improvement of Forestry Eco System”, “Building Bio-originated Economic System”, etc. have been integrated into the “Notice on National Forestry Reform” by the Forest Industry Group (Forest Authority. Biological conservation, e.g. wildlife (flora and fauna) protection, will be integrated in
“Inner Mongolia Forest 13th 5-year Plan”, which has been formulating since late 2014. In April 2015, Inner Mongolia Forest Industry Group (Forest Authority) has been approved by the National Development and Reform Commission and other departments as a “Demonstration Area for Eco protection and construction”, thanks to the advices and support of the PCGs.

description.narrative: Expanded and more representative PA system approved Area of PAs upgraded to National status Area of PAs upgraded to Provincial status

comment.narrative: 3.10 million ha (including 1.27 million ha of natural wetlands) 1.00 million ha 1.32 million ha
4.20 million ha (including 2.05 million ha of natural wetlands) 1.57 million ha 1.44 million ha

An expanded and more representative PA system has been planned and initiated at provincial level, and that at the regional level will be done in 2016.
Overall, areas of PAs upgraded to national status increased by 71,460 hectares, and that upgraded to the provincial status by 106,288 hectares. In Heilongjiang, 3 new National Wetland Parks (pilots) were established increasing PA areas by 14,856 ha; 2 provincial nature reserves were newly designated covering an added protection area of 68,612 hectares.
In Inner Mongolia, 1 natural reserve was upgraded to national level with a protection area of 56,604 hectares, and the area of newly upgraded provincial NR is 37,676 hectares.

comment.narrative: The sum total is ?4.8846 million yuan in RMB, equivalent to US$787,800. In 2014, annual operational budgets for PAs in Heilongjiang’s five NNR was ?2.344 million yuan more than that in 2013; of Inner Mongolia’s 3 NNR, the figure was ?2.5406 million yuan more than that in 2013.

description.narrative: Number of trained staff with certified competency standards

comment.narrative: 300 PA trainees to competency standards in at least 5 subject modules

A total of 238 people were given training, including 63 from Heilongjiang, 175 from Inner Mongolia. Besides, more people, e.g. governmental officers in charge, project staff and PA managers/staff, will be trained through an on-going subcontract entitled “Training for strengthening the systemic, institutional and operational capacity of PAs in Daxing’anling Landscape” to address technical gaps in PA staff skills.

description.narrative: Reduction in illegal incidents within the PAs – poaching, illegal harvesting, etc., despite improved activity of rangers

comment.narrative:
Inner Mongolia section: average of 2908 administrative cases and 79 criminal cases (2009 & 10)
Heilongjiang section: average of 95 administrative cases and 20 criminal cases (2010 & 11)
10% decrease from the baseline for each province section despite improved rangering

Inner Mongolia section: average of 37 administrative cases and 0 criminal cases (2014) Heilongjiang section: average of 4 administrative cases and 0 criminal cases (2014). In 2014, the Heilongjiang region assigned more than 3700 people-times and more than 1350 vehicles-times to inspect criminal cases related to biodiversity conservation on the market, restaurants and other establishments inspected 680 sites. Besides, a total of 118 unauthorized visitors/villagers were expelled from the PAs, more than 3500 passing vehicles were inspected, 870 hunting gear were impounded, more than 170 live birds released, 8 wildlife and wild animal products were impounded, and 4 wildlife cases were uncovered. In the Inner Mongolia area, there was no criminal case found in PAs during this period, thanks to the strengthened enforcement of relevant laws, regulations and policies by both the authorities and local people that has been greatly promoted and supported by the project. For example: Hanma National Reserve strengthened the monitoring and publicity, developed relevant work processes, systems and management practices, developed a wildlife patrol monitoring system, and carried out regular inspection, supervision and guidance of the implementation. A total of 30 automatic infrared cameras have been emplaced for effective monitoring in populous areas of wildlife. 16 additional wildlife monitoring sites have been established. Furthermore, several special reports and articles had been published for raising the public awareness. At the Erguna NNR, 5 times patrolling were carried out into the mountain areas, removed 2 sets of hunting gear, evicted 24 person/times of people illegally entered into the protected areas for construction, exploration, hunting and fishing purposes.

description.narrative: 3.2: a) determine fishing quota of the lake based on its ecological capacity; Incidence of encroachment of intensive fishing in lake habitats especially in core areas reduced; b) improve biodiversity and ecosystem health of Shengjin Lake, Anqing Riverine Wetlands and Shibasuo.

comment.narrative:
a) No fishing quota based on ecological capacity calculation; Encroachment is taking place; b) EHI:
Shengjin Lake 0.45, Anqing Riverine Wetlands 0.43, and Shibasuo 0.41.

Fishing quota determined; By end of project all fishing carried out according to established quotas and outside the core areas (Note: If economic activities are excluded from the core areas, there are no waters for them, and it is impossible to implement the component of the project (ecotourism, fisheries with quotas).;
EHI Targets
Shengjin Lake = 0.70
Anqing WPA = 0.61
Shibasuo WPA = 0.63

Self-assessment by WPAs staff:
Shengjin Lake = 0.52
Anqing WPA = 0.483
Shibasuo WPA = 0.47 The habitat connectivity, water supply and oxygen levels had been improved due to most of the fishing nets were moved in the upper and middle lakes of Shengjin Lake and the lake is restored gradually. All these aspects led the improvements in the Shengjin Lake EHI scores. Actions: The Integrated Shengjin Lake Basin Management Plan and other neighboring WPA plans will be developed. The project will also have sub-contracts to restore and demonstrate waterfowl habitat at the upper and middle lakes of Shengjin Lake, build small “artificial” wetland, have training and communication to reduce sewage emission through local community co-management.
Work of fishing quota and habitats restoration will start in the fourth quarter of 2015 in accordance with the project work-plan.

Reports of decrease in key wildfowl species.

At least 50% of the wildfowl habitats are restored (with at least 3 times natural aquatic vegetation than pre-restoration).
Population of key species remaining stable

The total population of key species (winter birds) reduced from 2012 to 2014. The corresponding actions planned. NRs and Local people in 5 WPAs patrol and monitor wetland biodiversity through co-management and the work of restoring and demonstrating waterfowl habitat at the upper and middle lakes of Shengjin Lake and neighboring WPAs will start from 2016 according to the work plan.

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration
The project will address the POPs/PTS release sensitive e-waste stream in the recycling, dismantling, treatment and final disposal processes of Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment (WEEE).
Efficient and functional EPR and WEEE management system

comment.narrative: EPR Treatment Fund established but not efficiently functional
National policy about EPR finalised.

This is the third year of EPR Treatment Fund implementation at the national level. (REMARK:The EPR treatment fund is implemented by government involved many ministries on July, 2012.) A more standard guideline on e-waste dismantling was updated. The policy on 9 new kinds of e-waste dismantling standard has been in progress of being updated, which will enable the EPR Treatment Fund to be implemented more smoothly.
Improved operational mechanism of EPR Treatment Fund and WEEE management
No further regulation was issued during this period. The policy research is in preparation.
At least 250 management personnel at national and demonstration locations trained on EPR concept and WEE management system.
63 management persons were trained in the last year. Three local PMOs organized the training by themselves.

description.narrative: Amount of WEEE treated by permitted recyclers in the three demonstration locations

comment.narrative: Over 2 million units of WEEE collected and processed by permitted recyclers at the 3 demonstration
Estimated 50% increased of WEEE collected and processed

Over 2 million units of WEEE were recollected and processed under the strict monitoring by local EPBs in our three demonstration provinces: Tianjin, Jiangsu and Hubei. Because of the huge statistics, the current data only reflects the dismantling WEEE from 1 July 2014 to 31 march 2015. The latest data will be calculated in next annual project report.

description.narrative: Number of facilities replicating or establishing sound WEEE recycling

comment.narrative: At least 2 BAT/BEP technologies for pretreatment demonstrated and relevant technical guidelines finalised
N/A

At least 2 BAT/BEP technologies for disposal demonstrated, end gas discharge of PCDD/PCDF to meet pollution control standards for hazardous waste incineration if incineration technology selected. Relevant technical guidelines finalised.
N/A

description.narrative: Number of workers received training in sound WEEE processing

comment.narrative: At least 25,000 technical workers trained on BAT/BEP and sound WEEE processing

At the first year of project implementation, all of the trainings were organized by demonstration areas themselves. For example, Xiangyu from Jiangsu province invited technical expert Mr. Wei to give their technical workers process and safety training twice last year. Bowang from Hubei province invited technical expert from Wuhan University to give their technical workers process and safety training twice during this period. Around 6,300 workers were trained in three demonstration areas.

description.narrative: Market based WEEE processing infrastructure demonstrated and developed

comment.narrative: Low rate of WEEE collection and recycling by formal sector
Demonstration of collection successfully completed at selected enterprises
Work in Progress. Three subcontracts were signed in demonstration areas. Multi-channel recycling ways were operated in the enterprises to reach the recycling goal as planned.
Dominated by primitive and manual processing of WEEE
Technology demonstration activities at selected enterprises at the three demonstration provinces/municipality successfully completed

Ongoing. Three subcontracts were signed with Local Project Management Offices. Parts of the production lines were updated in the first year, for example, Xiangyu in Jiangsu Province added a new TV dismantling line, TCL in Tianjin added some new dust exhausts on their original TV dismantling line. 3 LPMOs assumed responsibility for project implementation in each of their respective demonstration area and gathered required information as planned.
Over 5,000 tons of Brominated Flame Retardants (BFR) containing plastic/resins performed/reused annually
15,000 tons of Brominated Flame Retardants (BFR) containing plastic/resins processed was estimated. About 24 kg of BFRs were processed safely in this period.
Over 5,000 tons of CRT to be recycled annually from environmental emission annually in the demonstration locations
N/A
5 WEEE technical guidelines about eco-design finalised.
N/A
Eco-design for at least one electrical and electronic equipment developed

Ongoing. The project is liaising with the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT), who is the most relevant to the electronics manufacturing industry, responsible for encouraging cleaner production and eco-design of electrical and electronic equipment, as well as providing technical and policy support to MOF, MOC, NDRC and MEP on development and implementation of the WEEE management system including identification of technology requirements.

description.narrative: Informal WEEE processing facilities upgraded and integrated into EPR system through diversion into informal processing facilities

comment.narrative: Large percentage of WEEE is estimated to be collected and processed by the informal sector
Three types of WEEE collection/recycling demonstrated and successfully completed at three selected provinces/municipality.

description.narrative: Number of newly registered WEEE processors

comment.narrative: Zero.(No more enterprises became to the registered WEEE processors
Increase WEEE collected and channeled by informal or newly registered (ex-informal) collectors to formal recycling enterprises for treatment

At the end of the 2013, 91 WEEE processors had been established. By the end of 2014, 106 WEEE processors were registered totally by the MEP, which were considered as national activities in this project. At the next step, the project will revise the WEEE processor register regulation because of 9 new type e-wastes involved.

description.narrative: At least one public awareness campaign conducted every year

comment.narrative: None. Level of awareness to be established during first year of implementation
3 public awareness campaigns conducted in the demonstration provinces/municipality

Every LPMO organized public awareness campaign at province level. For example, the TCL from Tianjin was jointly Baidu recycling launched by UNDP, MEP, involving film star Ms.Zhao Wei as advocate with both local and international news coverage in August, 2014. Hubei PMO made a short video broadcast in Wuhan city subway from 4th to 6th June, 2015. Jiangsu PMO combined Jiangsu Tencent launching an O2O way in e-waste recycle in May 2015. All of the activities provided public awareness on e-waste as well as to where the e-waste was sent.
